items.title: 'Mr. Trump, stop killing American citizens,' Kinew says after 2nd fatal shooting in Minnesota
items.summary_auto: Manitoba's premier says he's reached out to his counterpart in Minnesota again following the killing of another American citizen by federal immigration officials, calling on U.S. President Donald Trump to stop the violence.

items.title: Trump and U.S. government have declared war on Minneapolis, says former mayor
items.summary_auto: Former mayor of Minneapolis R. T. Rybak says people in his city are coming together against what he sees as an attack from the U.S. federal government.

items.title: Most NDP MPs unable to get to Ottawa for return of Parliament due to weather delays
items.summary_auto: Most NDP MPs were unable to get to Ottawa today for the return of Parliament after weather-related travel issues stranded several of them in Rankin Inlet, Nunavut.

items.title: Remember when Toronto called in the military to clear snow? Here's how this storm compares
items.summary_auto: Toronto Pearson Airport recorded 46 centimetres of snow on Sunday — the highest daily snowfall there on record. But it's still not as bad as 1999, the year Toronto called in the military for help.

items.title: Canada's ski cross, alpine ski racers unveiled for Milano-Cortina Olympics
items.summary_auto: World champions Jack Crawford, Laurence St-Germain and Marielle Thompson lead Canada's alpine ski team into the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympic Games.

items.title: What Habs captain Nick Suzuki thinks of the hit series Heated Rivalry
items.summary_auto: The Montreal Canadiens centre and three of his teammates, Juraj Slafkovský, Oliver Kapanen and Alexandre Texier, were guests on Radio-Canada’s Tout le monde en parle on Jan. 25. They’re preparing to represent their respective countries in the upcoming Milano-Cortina Olympics.

items.title: Recall of Pizza Pops expands due to possible links to E. coli outbreak
items.summary_auto: The Canadian Food Inspection Agency says a recall of select Pizza Pops products announced before Christmas has been expanded.

items.title: Minnesota asks courts to curtail immigration blitz after 2 shootings as Trump sends his border czar
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump said on social media on Monday that he is sending border czar Tom Homan to Minnesota, two days after a second U.S. citizen was shot and killed by officers working for the federal government in its immigration operations in the state.

items.title: Sinner extends winning streak to 18 at Australian Open, advances to men's quarterfinals
items.summary_auto: Jannik Sinner wasn't shaky or lucky to survive this time and the only thing hot on Monday was his streak, which now stands at 18 straight wins at the Australian Open.

items.title: Canadian swim star Ilya Kharun, who won 2 bronze medals at Paris Olympics, says he'll now compete for U.S.
items.summary_auto: Swimmer Ilya Kharun, one of Canada’s most promising athletes in the pool, has decided to compete for the United States.

items.title: Toronto-area clean-up will take days as Pearson airport smashes snowfall record
Gold hits record $5,000 US an ounce as months-long rally continues amid global turmoil
items.summary_auto: Gold charged past $5,000 US an ounce for the first time on Monday — while silver jumped to $110 an ounce — as an array of geopolitical tensions pounded the U.S. dollar.

items.title: Israel recovers remains of final hostage in Gaza, opening way for next phase
items.summary_auto: Israel has recovered the remains of the last remaining hostage held in Gaza, the military said on Monday, fulfilling a key condition of the initial phase of U.S. President Donald Trump's plan to end the war in the Palestinian territory.

items.title: Woman found dead in Montreal West home during power outage
items.summary_auto: A 66-year-old woman was found dead inside her home on Hudson Avenue in Montreal West on Sunday. Montreal firefighters were performing wellness checks in the area due to power outages, and discovered the woman unconscious at around 6 p.m.

items.title: Military helicopters to be seen over B.C., Alberta, Yukon as part of Canada-U.S. training exercise
items.summary_auto: Exercise STRIKING BAT also sees Canadian forces working alongside Norway, Italy and Mongolia.

items.title: At least 18 dead, hundreds rescued after ferry sinks in Philippines
items.summary_auto: A ferry with more than 350 people on board sank early Monday near an island in the southern Philippines, killing at least 18 people, officials said. Rescuers saved hundreds more, while a fleet of coast guard and naval ships searched for those still missing.

items.title: Plane involved in fatal crash in Maine had history of problems
items.summary_auto: The business jet that crashed Sunday evening while trying to take off in a snowstorm in Maine and killed at least a half dozen people is a plane model that has a history of problems with crashes caused by ice buildup on the wings.

items.title: Stephen Miller: ICE’s ideologue-in-chief
items.summary_auto: Top White House advisor Stephen Miller has been called the driving force behind Donald Trump’s domestic agenda – including the aggressive ICE escalation in Minneapolis. We’ve got a deep look at his life and beliefs.

items.title: N.W.T. government won't administer federal gun buyback program
items.summary_auto: For some N.W.T. residents, participating in the federal gun buyback program might not be so straightforward. The Government of the Northwest Territories says it’s not going to administer it.

items.title: 'He deserves to be heard': Mother fights for non-verbal son to use preferred communication method at school
items.summary_auto: Jude Valant, a 19-year-old non-verbal student with severe autism, relies on a communication method called Rapid Prompting Method to express his thoughts. His school won’t allow its use because it is not a recognized form of communication.

items.title: Family of Quebec couple found dead in Dominican Republic disputes cause of death findings
items.summary_auto: The family of a Gatineau, Que., couple found dead while staying in the Dominican Republic earlier this winter is disputing the official cause of death given by local authorities.

items.title: Radon gas may be giving more Canadians lung cancer. Scientists are racing to save lives
items.summary_auto: Radon gas, an invisible health threat that can build up in your home, is putting more Canadians at risk of deadly lung cancer. A national research team is using throwaway toenail clippings to find markers of high radon exposure, in the hope of expanding cancer screenings to save lives.

items.title: History, war museums to slash dozens of positions
items.summary_auto: The Canadian Museum of History and the Canadian War Museum will be cutting permanent staff levels by 18 per cent over the next three years due to cuts announced in the federal budget.

items.title: Activist warns of ‘propaganda’ as CSIS officials tout agency’s new approach to Indigenous people
items.summary_auto: Officials at the Canadian Security Intelligence Service say the organization is mending its ways and acknowledging past investigating of Indigenous people has left a legacy of mistrust that persists today. One activist, however, is dismissing the overtures as propaganda.

items.title: Disabled man feels shut out of accessible seating as venues — including Rogers Arena — fail to stop abuse
items.summary_auto: With no requirement to prove eligibility, accessible seats at major sports and entertainment venues across the country are sold on the honour system — sometimes leaving people who rely on wheelchairs and other mobility aids unable to get tickets.

items.title: Kelowna, B.C., sentencing halted after court learns accused overdosed during lunch break
items.summary_auto: The sentencing hearing for a Kelowna woman who killed her boyfriend with a vehicle in 2022 came to an abrupt halt on Friday, after the court heard the accused had been hospitalized.
